The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class was a great opportunity to bring together both PhD and master's students with research interests in water to discuss current research (by students or others). I really appreciated the opportunity to learn about what other students were working on and stay abreast of interesting findings in the field. It was also a good opportunity for students to practice public speaking skills in a supportive environment.

I really didn't feel like this class met my expectations. I didn't really learn anything new, though I had the opportunity to present my research which was good. That was really the only benefit I saw honestly.

This course was a one-credit seminar on Fresh Water Topics and I expected the professor to develop curriculum that the class would follow to be sure we got the most out of the class as possible. Yet, I was disappointed with the class. The professor did not prepare anything for the course. He assigned no readings and no homework and did not lead discussions. By assigning student-led presentations for every class, the class felt disjointed and did not follow a theme nor allow me to develop a base of knowledge on the topics presented. It felt more like a PhD class where students presented their research as practice. It did not feel like a course that was truly open to students not conducting their own research, although it was promoted this way.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Pictures of baby beavers. Allowing master's students who are not doing current research to talk about interesting research related to water was nice. It was a good mix.
Exposure to the research and interests of fellow students, valuable feedback, and practice presenting.
For those who has research and interested in a particular topic of freshwater, this course offers a great place for discussion and sharing experiences.
I liked that people have the opportunity to share projects that they were working on but it didn't feel like really enough time or in enough depth to be useful.
Learning about other aspects of water research at FES
The flexibility of deciding on what topic to present and what date each of us would present to the class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Pretty good overall, but maybe a field trip to someone's research site would be nice (especially if it's just across the road).

I think it just needs a little bit more structure... The free-form structure can be kind of difficult, and the course only being an hour doesn't really allow for enough discussion. I could see this course being really useful if we dove into topics that were really difficult to grapple with, rather than having people present for the full-time and then just having a question-and-answer session. The format just doesn't make the course for useful or thought-provoking. There are so many issues with freshwater resources, and I feel like we didn't really even scratch the surface.

I would prefer if the class has structure and the professor led the class in some kind of discussion each class. The student-led presentations did not follow any kind of theme or topic structure. If the students had presented their research based on a general outline for the semester, it would have felt much more useful and engaging. If the professor had invested more time in the course and presented something at the beginning of each class or simply led a short discussion at the beginning or end of each class, I believe I would have learned more. Although it was only one-credit, based on other one-credit classed that I have loved, I feel as if the professor could have given more time to this class and helped it be a more meaningful experience for the students.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Ideally, I saw this is kind of an advanced seminar in freshwater topics, but it wasn't really advanced at all, and was very superficial. Despite doing the readings, we had very little opportunity to discuss them in any kind of critical way. I thought this course not only would be a great opportunity to get feedback on my research, but also discuss topics that are difficult to grapple with in this particular context, but it seemed like everyone presented very general topics, and not anything really specific to what they were doing and their perspective, which is what I really wanted to learn about.
It is very instructive

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To keep in touch with other students interested in water from an academic standpoint
I am interested in freshwater management
I took this course to gain more fluency and some of the current issues related to freshwater resources. But I just feel like I know just a little bit about some topics now.
I was interested in hearing what other students were doing research on.

I had hoped to get a general understanding of many different fresh water topics to help build up my knowledge base on the issues facing us today. Rather, I did not get out of this class what I hoped to. The research presented was very specific and did not speak to problems that most people are dealing with today, thus it felt more like a PhD research seminar, especially since many of the students were advisees of the professor and often discussed specific research that they were doing together, which did not feel inclusive.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes. the class exposed me to a several issues on managing freshwater.
Not really.
Yes
No.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Jim is great. Volunteer to present early in the semester.

Think about who's in the class and make your decision based on that. We all bring to the class what we've been working on, and it was kind of a mixed bag.I thought it would be more of a research seminar but it ended up being kind of more management related with not a lot of depth.
Take the course
Please know that it has no structure and the topics are completely chosen by the students and is mostly technical research.
